awd_titl_txt: SusChEM:  Building Superior Sustainable Polymers with Bioaromatics
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Polymer Program of the Division of Materials Research, Professor Stephen Miller of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Florida is developing new types of degradable plastics made from biorenewable sources (bioplastics), such as sugarcane waste.  These new types of plastics have shown some success in replacing commercial plastics made from petroleum feed stocks. However, a major barrier to their adoption is the inferior mechanical and degradation properties of most bioplastics relative to the petroleum-derived plastics.  Professor Miller and his research group are studying ways to convert inexpensive agricultural wastes or forestry wastes into feedstocks for making new types of bioplastics.  Feedstocks derived from such waste streams do not compete with agricultural food sources.  They are focusing on chemistry for making plastics that show desirable mechanical behaviors and that degrade under the appropriate environmental conditions.  Professor Miller is also providing research training to graduate students and preparing them for future careers in sustainability science and engineering. 

Professor Miller is designing and synthesizing new classes of polyesters and polyacetals based on the bioaromatics, vanillin and ferulic acid.  Available in large scale from a paper mill, corn stover, or sugarcane bagasse, these bioaromatics are key structural components to achieving high glass transition temperature materials with desirable thermomechanical properties.  Strategies being examined to control thermal properties and degradation behavior include use of bioaromatics as polymer pendent groups, the creation of bioaromatic polysilicon acetals, and the copolymerization of bioaromatics with chemically recycled bis-hydroxyethylterephthalate, from post-consumer poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET). Nature also abundantly supplies isosorbide, ascorbic acid, erythritol, itaconic acid, and dimethylsuccinyl succinate. Professor Miller is also studying ways to prepare polyesters, polyacetals, or polyamides with cyclic motifs present in the polymer main-chain from these bio-based molecules.  The resulting polymers are predicted to possess chain rigidity, higher glass transition temperature, and programmable degradability.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
There are alternative and sustainable biomass feedstocks which have begun and will continue to replace fossil fuels as the source for polymer building blocks—including polysaccharides, lignin, and triglycerides.  As these alternative, sustainable feedstocks increase in popularity and scale, they will provide economically competitive carbon-based biorefinery feedstocks from which to build polymers.  There are two critical motivations for conducting fundamental research in pursuit of novel, sustainable thermoplastics: (1) fossil fuel-based feedstocks are finite; and (2) the trash crisis is becoming a major environmental concern.  The overarching goal of this project was the synthesis, characterization, and property delineation of novel thermoplastic polymers built from bioaromatics and other biogenic cyclic monomers (biocyclics).  We specifically targeted polyesters, polyamides, and polyacetals that can mimic the thermal properties of incumbent, high-volume packaging plastics.  It is well known that aromatic and cyclic structures present in fossil fuel-based polymers typically confer "improved" thermal characteristics, including high glass transition temperatures.  For example, polyethylene terephthalate (PET) and polystyrene (PS) can be employed in their transparent, amorphous forms because their aromatic components provide a high glass transition temperature (Tg = 72 °C and 95 °C, respectively), suitable for high temperature applications (e.g., hot beverages in PS). 

The project results have been disseminated in a series of thirteen publications.  These describe a spectrum of results, from fundamental studies to practical and economical solutions.  Highlights from these thirteen papers include:  •Polylactam esters are readily made from biobased itaconic acid and are compared to polylactic acid.  The lactam ring improves the glass transition temperature and the main-chain ester groups are more readily hydrolyzed, degrading fully via agitation in water for one year.  •Bioaromatic polyacetals were synthesized via acid-catalyzed acetal formation from dialdehydes and tetraols.  •Concurrent ring-opening polymerization/polycondensation of lactones and bioaromatic hydroxy-acids yields random copolymers with improved and controlled thermal properties.  •Water-degradable polyvinyl acetals with high glass transition temperatures (114–157 °C) were made via acetalization of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) with bioaromatic aldehydes.  •This review describes recent strategies for synthesizing polymers that are mostly or fully biobased and exhibit a high glass transition temperature.  •Biosuccinic acid, obtained via sugar fermentation, is cyclodimerized and oxidized to yield building blocks for aromatic polyesters with high glass transition temperatures.  •Chemoenzymatic methods are crucial for the efficient synthesis of cellulose-derived acrylate monomers, which afford polymers with tuneable and high glass transition temperatures.  •Sugar-derived diols are copolymerized with terpene-derived camphoric acid to yield polyesters with high glass transition temperatures and an unusual susceptibility to hydrolytic degradation.  •The origins and recent applications of acetal metathesis are discussed in the context of synthesizing polyacetals via acetal metathesis polymerization (AMP).  •The green homocoupling of cellulose-derived levoglucosenone and subsequent Baeyer-Villiger oxidation provide a new 100 % bio-based monomer (2H-HBO-HBO), which was polymerized to create new, sustainable polyesters.  •Water-degradable polyvinyl ketals with high glass transition temperatures (78–127 °C) were made via ketalization of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) with sustainable ketones.  •Herein, we review the preparation of competitive (meth)acrylates and the corresponding polymers made from bio-renewable sources with a specific focus on lignocellulose.  •High melting bio-based polyesters were synthesized from HO-HBO, a chiral diol readily sourced from cellulose.  As shown in the corresponding graphic, seven of these papers were illustrated on journal covers.  Additionally this research resulted in eight Ph.D. Theses, one Masters Thesis, and two issued U.S. Patents.

This NSF award has provided research and educational opportunities to about fourteen graduate students and five undergraduate students.   Also, this NSF award has facilitated their realization that new ideas and projects in organic chemistry and polymer chemistry will result in useful environmental technologies.  The fields of Environmental Science and Sustainability will be positively impacted by the results and findings from this project.  Simply stated, the threat of exhausting our fossil fuel supplies dictates that we must soon identify alternative feedstocks for polymer synthesis.  This proposal targeted the synthesis and characterization of new thermoplastic materials that readily derive from biorenewable aromatics and imitate many of the desirable thermomechanical properties currently available from commodity packaging plastics derived from petrochemicals.  Yet, they possess eco-friendly and tunable degradation behavior.  We have made genuine advances demonstrating that polymers from renewable feedstocks can have the required thermal properties to replace fossil fuel-based plastics. 


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Stephen A Miller

Image
  • Seven of the thirteen published papers were illustrated on journal covers.
    Stephen A. Miller
    Copyrighted
    Stephen A Miller
    Seven Cover Graphics - NSF

There are alternative and sustainable biomass feedstocks which have begun and will continue to replace fossil fuels as the source for polymer building blocks—including polysaccharides, lignin, and triglycerides.  As these alternative, sustainable feedstocks increase in popularity and scale, they will provide economically competitive carbon-based biorefinery feedstocks from which to build polymers. It is well known that aromatic and cyclic structures present in fossil fuel-based polymers typically confer "improved" thermal characteristics, including high glass transition temperatures.  For example, polyethylene terephthalate (PET) and polystyrene (PS) can be employed in their transparent, amorphous forms because their aromatic components provide a high glass transition temperature (Tg = 72 °C and 95 °C, respectively), suitable for high temperature applications (e.g., hot beverages in PS). 

The project results have been disseminated in a series of thirteen publications.  These describe a spectrum of results, from fundamental studies to practical and economical solutions. Additionally this research resulted in eight Ph.D. Theses, one Masters Thesis, and two issued U.S. Patents.

This NSF award has provided research and educational opportunities to about fourteen graduate students and five undergraduate students.   Also, this NSF award has facilitated their realization that new ideas and projects in organic chemistry and polymer chemistry will result in useful environmental technologies.  The fields of Environmental Science and Sustainability will be positively impacted by the results and findings from this project.  Simply stated, the threat of exhausting our fossil fuel supplies dictates that we must soon identify alternative feedstocks for polymer synthesis. Yet, they possess eco-friendly and tunable degradation behavior.
